data.title: Enable ANGLE for Windows 7 and below
data.body:
Godot [compiles with ANGLE](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/commits/master/platform/winrt/include/angle_gl.h) for UWP builds (`winrt`), so #3634 is no more actual (there is choice to use Godot on Windows). However, it only works for Windows 8 and above.

It would be nice to backport support for [ANGLE](https://chromium.googlesource.com/angle/angle/+/master/README.md) backend to non-UWP platforms, such as Windows 7 and below. ANGLE may also be used to run Godot on systems with Vulkan (#3729) drivers, but without OpenGL support (which sounds kind of strange).

data.title: Global normalmaps and shaders kill switches
data.body: It would be nice to have an option that's capable of turning off shaders and normalmaps on every node that has those assigned. This would allow for better graphics control in games and let people with older PCs to get a performance boost without much trouble of going through all the objects in GDscript and checking them for normalmaps/shaders by yourself.

data.title: Project manager: grab focus on ok button after path selection.
data.body:
Slight usability improvement: grabs focus on the Import/Create button after engine.cfg/path selection.
So then I can just press enter to create the project ^^

data.title: Fix crash on variable export. Disallow Object Types as values for "export"(ed) vars.
data.body:
Fix #6719 crash

Writing:

```
export var path = Path
```

would crash the engine.
Now it properly reports an error.

data.title: trunc(vector_type) broken in shaders (causes runtime GLSL compile failure)
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Godot 2.2a linux x11 AMD FX8320 (8-core) 16GB RAM

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
The following code fails to compile in a shader:

F-shader (also triggers on V-shader - I never tested with L-shader):
vec3 vector_with_floaties=vec3(1.41421,2.71828,3.14159);
vec3 integral_vector=trunc(vector_with_floaties); // <-- fails to compile
// workaruond: vec3 integral_vector=vector_with_floaties-fract(vector_with_floaties);

No errors occur in the editor but the scene will have the tell-tale dull-grey shade (indicating shader didn't run) errors messages will have logged in Debug and the errors are visible in full when using the console (it's not possible to read the error in the Debug window due to the huge one-liner error message in a view that has no scrollbar).

**Steps to reproduce:**
See above.

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
See above.

data.title: Godot program crash.
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
Windows 10, v2.1.stable.official

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
If you add this code into you script. 

`Export var path = Path`

or some like that it will crash godot if you click on a another node in the tree or try to save. and if you save this as your start up scene it will crash godot every time you open it even if your not doing anything.

**Steps to reproduce:**
Open godot create a script add this code `Export var path = Path` (Please note it's not just the path one it will crash if you use other ones to.) and click on a node in the tree view

**Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome):
[Bug.zip](https://github.com/godotengine/godot/files/512528/Bug.zip)

data.title: AnimationPlayer editor: Ability to copy individual keys
data.body:
I found myself having to move a key with a number of arguments in an func call track in the animation editor to another animation inside the same node, but it seems to not be possible to copy a single individual key. 

It'd be really convenient to allow copying/cutting selected keys to the clipboard so they can be pasted to a different animation. While this is mostly useful for func call tracks, it'd also be useful in regular node parameter ones, specially with multi-part sprites where certain positions/parameters are repeated in different animations.

data.title: Crash To Desktop on switching focus in GridContainer containing complex buttons.
data.body: **Operating system or device - Godot version:** Mac OSX El Capitan. Godot v2.1.stable.official **Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected): I am making a slightly more complex button. It has to support lighting, and animations, and thus is a complex tree including a couple of Node2D nodes. When putting a bunch of instances of them on a GridContainer, and trying to switch focus using tab produces a Crash to Desktop **Steps to reproduce:** To do this I created two scenes: -one with a container and a GridContainer. -one that is the button. It has a Container, a Node2D and a Button. I add several instances of the button to the GridContainer on its _ready method. Then launch it, click on one of the buttons and press "tab". Crash to Desktop and OSX asks to fill a report. Do note that moving around with the keys (reaaaally nice feature jesus christ thanks to whoever did this) does not produce a crash. **Link to minimal example project** (optional but very welcome): data.title: On-demand shader compilation causes hiccups
data.body:
(Not using the template as this is a very general issue.)

By design, Godot's rasterizer setups shaders for both 2D and 3D elements as they are needed during render. It creates different versions of each shader for any context it's used on, with different set of defines for every case.

This is sensible as long as it would be a waste of time and memory to precompile every shader for every use case. For instance, if a material in 3D is never used in the alpha pass, that variant won't ever get compiled. There are a number of combinations for both 2D and 3D materials.

The downside is that **the first frame of a scene just loaded with several different materials/shaders takes much more time because of the compilation of shaders, causing a noticebale hiccup**. And, as long as I can guess, as soon as any mesh or sprite with a not-yet-compiled shader enters the viewport it will happen again.

In my game I'm calling `VisualServer.draw()` on the main scene's `_ready()` to force compilation of at least the shaders needed for the first screen without affecting the timing, thus avoiding the hiccup.

Is there any reasonable implementation that could avoid that yet being more reliable?

I'm willing to implement it. I even started adding a method, `VisualServer.prepare_all_materials()`, but precompiling every combination is cumbersome and wasteful so I need a better approach.

Does anybody know how is this handled in other engines?

data.title: fix #6012 exposed setters and getters of Camera H/V offset to GDScript
Add shortcut to reset cursor position in 3D Editor ( #166 )
data.body:
The shortcut will focus the origin after you moved around with shift + mouse3.
The default shortcut is the letter "O", like "F" for focus.
This can be customized in the editor shortcuts menu.

Closes #166

data.title: fix #6031 when creating a script the default language will be what yo
data.body: u selected last time

data.title: Convert resource files to binary on export
data.body:
Feature request.

So **.tres** and **.xml** files (which are not `PackedScene`, as it's already handled) can get converted to binary on export like it's possible now with scenes.
If you inspect a packed game it's a bit ugly that the scenes are in binary but `.tres` files are still plain text.

data.title: fix #6031 when creating a script the default language will be what you selected last time
Expose selected value of GraphNode
data.body: It's needed when making plugin with `GraphEdit` to know which `GraphNode` is selected.

data.title: Add editor_only param to Light2D
data.body:
Since it's useful for 2D as well.

Already protected against #6665 with the same logic as #6693.

data.title: Fix GraphEdit grab random node when delete or deselect by clicking empty space
Fix compile flags not getting to the Android build
data.body:
`C*FLAGS` are correctly passed to compilation for desktop but were completely overwritten by the Android build sub-script (probably it was assumed they were empty anyway, but that's not necessarily the case).

Now it appends flags instead of overwriting.

data.title: fixes #6695 - MultiNodeEdit edit path in exported NodePath
data.body: Someone should verify this as I am not sure it is 100% correct :D

data.title: Add error when (pre)loading paths with leading / (#4280 - #3106)
data.body:
Calling "load", "extends" and "preload" with absolute paths not including the drive (e.g. `/script/myscript.gd`) causes a series of unexpected behavior (see #3106 and #4280).

With this PR those commands will throw an error if you try to use a path with a leading slash.
As the error message states the path must either specify the drive or be local, e.g. `res://path/to/file.gd` `path/to/file.gd`

data.title: ConnectionDialog: Don't allow connecting to a Node without a script if target method is invalid.
data.body:
Shows an error now.
Fixes #6656

data.title: Export to telegram gaming platform
data.body:
https://telegram.org/blog/games

For that, Godot needs three things:
1. tell if current game is exportable
2. tell what to fix if it is non-exportable 
3. export template

data.title: fixes #6331, Variant::can_convert
Fixes hash float negative 0 problem
data.body:
Before this was giving an error:

```
var a = {Vector2(1, 0): 5, Vector2(-1, 0): 7}
print(a)
print(a[Vector2(1, 0)])
print(a[-Vector2(1, 0)])
```

This simple commit fixes the issue.

data.title: AnimationPlayer Sprite:frame weird behavior
data.body:
**Operating system or device - Godot version:**
2.1 stable

**Issue description** (what happened, and what was expected):
Animating spritesheets is becoming a real pain in the ass. I have no idea what is going with the AnimationPlayer anymore :(

Take this spritesheet for example:

![normal-punch](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10387670/19065318/bbfc23d6-89c7-11e6-82ce-aad34f40ad9f.png)

5 frames.

Steps to reproduce:
- Add a Sprite and AnimationPlayer node 
- Change Sprites texture to the above sprite
- Create a new animation, name it "puncher"
- Set the animation length to 0.3
- Set the Sprite's `VFrames` to `1`, and `HFrames` to `5`
- Insert a keyframe at 0 seconds for the first `frame` (`0`)
- Now, go to the last time in the timeline (0.3seconds) and insert a new keyframe for `frame`. The last fame is index `4` (0,1,2,3,4) = 5 frames. 
- It will show the punching sprite with the label "5"
- Now on the animation track, set the animation mode to `Continuous`. So it looks something like this:

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10387670/19065508/d16db544-89c8-11e6-98d3-9eabede519c1.png)

Now, start to drag the line in the animation player from left to right (Beginning to End), **it stops on frame 4? Why?**

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10387670/19065585/3137cbb8-89c9-11e6-9cd9-d356845636a5.png)

But, you can actually fix this, buy clicking on the last keyframe, and changing the value to `5`:
![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10387670/19065608/49d50a78-89c9-11e6-9a92-fb8705405545.png)

Then, when you click enter, it will still show 4 (since there is only 4 frames in the spritesheet, counting index) so that's correct. But, now drag the animation timeline from left to right again... It now stops on frame 5 which is correct..

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/10387670/19065636/6e65b02c-89c9-11e6-844f-56aa683ab1c8.png)
